articles.headline: In Enron Case, a Verdict on an Era
articles.snippet: The Enron trial painted a broad and disturbing portrait of a corporate culture poisoned by hubris.
articles.abstract: The Enron trial painted a broad and disturbing portrait of a corporate culture poisoned by hubris.
articles.lead_paragraph: Guilty of crimes — and a whole lot more.

articles.headline: Phone Tax Laid to Rest at Age 108
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. will refund taxes paid on long-distance telephone service over the past three years.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. will refund taxes paid on long-distance telephone service over the past three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Enron Jury Unswayed by 'I Didn't Know'
articles.snippet: The jurors said they simply could not believe that Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were telling the truth when they claimed they didn't realize that something was rotten at Enron.
articles.abstract: The jurors said they simply could not believe that Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were telling the truth when they claimed they didn't realize that something was rotten at Enron.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 25 — One after another, the jurors spoke and, in different voices, it all added up to the same thing.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Kyle Whitmire

articles.headline: Election Battle: Will Peltz Win in Heinz Vote?
articles.snippet: The big election campaign of 2006--for a minority of the board seats at H. J. Heinz, the food company--got off to a rousing start this week
articles.abstract: The big election campaign of 2006--for a minority of the board seats at H. J. Heinz, the food company--got off to a rousing start this week
articles.lead_paragraph: THE big election campaign of 2006 got off to a rousing start this week, with the incumbents denounced for "excessive costs and inefficiency" that had hurt voters who deserved better.

articles.headline: Two Enron Chiefs Are Convicted in Fraud and Conspiracy Trial
articles.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were found guilty of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday. Sentencing is set for the week of Sept. 11.
articles.abstract: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were found guilty of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday. Sentencing is set for the week of Sept. 11.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 25 — Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the chief executives who guided Enron through its spectacular rise and even more stunning fall, were found guilty Thursday of fraud and conspiracy. They are among the most prominent corporate leaders convicted in the parade of scandals that marked the get-rich-quick excesses and management failures of the 1990’s.

articles.headline: Bush and Blair Concede Errors, but Defend War
articles.snippet: The two leaders insisted that the election of a constitutional government in Iraq justified going to war.
articles.abstract: The two leaders insisted that the election of a constitutional government in Iraq justified going to war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 — President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, two leaders badly weakened by the continuing violence in Iraq, acknowledged major misjudgments in the execution of the Iraq war on Thursday night even while insisting that the election of a constitutional government in Baghdad justified their decision to go to war three years ago.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Atop Hedge Funds, Richest of the Rich Get Even More So
articles.snippet: In 2005 there were 26 hedge fund managers who made $130 million or more.  The top two each made more than $1 billion.
articles.abstract: In 2005 there were 26 hedge fund managers who made $130 million or more.  The top two each made more than $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about minting money. In 2001 and 2002, hedge fund managers had to make $30 million to gain entry to a survey of the best paid in hedge funds that is closely followed by people in the business. In 2004, the threshold had soared to $100 million.

articles.headline: Abbas Says Hamas Must Accept Peace Plan or Face Referendum
articles.snippet: Mahmoud Abbas said that he would call a referendum if Hamas failed to accept the peace plan within 10 days.
articles.abstract: Mahmoud Abbas said that he would call a referendum if Hamas failed to accept the peace plan within 10 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 25 — The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that he would call a referendum on a proposal for a Palestinian state that would recognize Israel, if the governing Hamas party failed to accept the plan within 10 days.

articles.headline: Military to Report Marines Killed Iraqi Civilians
articles.snippet: An investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis is expected to find that a small number of marines carried out extensive, unprovoked killing of civilians.
articles.abstract: An investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis is expected to find that a small number of marines carried out extensive, unprovoked killing of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 — A military investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis last November is expected to find that a small number of marines in western Iraq carried out extensive, unprovoked killings of civilians, Congressional, military and Pentagon officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, Eric Schmitt and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Enron Jury Unswayed by 'I Didn't Know'
articles.snippet: One after another, the jurors spoke and, in different voices, it all added up to the same thing.     They simply could not believe, the eight women and four men of the jury explained in an extraordinary joint news conference after rendering their ...
articles.abstract: One after another, the jurors spoke and, in different voices, it all added up to the same thing.     They simply could not believe, the eight women and four men of the jury explained in an extraordinary joint news conference after rendering their verdict, that Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling were telling the truth when they claimed they didn't realize that something was rotten at Enron.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 25 - One after another, the jurors spoke and, in different voices, it all added up to the same thing.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Kyle Whitmire

articles.headline: Abbas Says Hamas Must Accept Peace Plan or Face Referendum
articles.snippet: The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that he would call a referendum on a proposal for a Palestinian state that would recognize Israel, if the governing Hamas party failed to accept the plan within 10 days.     ...
articles.abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that he would call a referendum on a proposal for a Palestinian state that would recognize Israel, if the governing Hamas party failed to accept the plan within 10 days.      In laying down his challenge, Mr. Abbas seems to be gambling that he can force his Fatah party, Hamas and some smaller factions to agree on a broad framework for dealing with Israel, which Hamas now refuses to recognize. But he runs the risk of provoking a political showdown at a moment when the Palestinians are already plagued by infighting and a worsening financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 25 - The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, said Thursday that he would call a referendum on a proposal for a Palestinian state that would recognize Israel, if the governing Hamas party failed to accept the plan within 10 days.

articles.headline: Border Fight Divides G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The negotiations between the White House and Congress that will follow the Senate's passage on Thursday of an immigration bill could decide not just how the nation confronts illegal immigration but also what strain of conservatism the Republican P...
articles.abstract: The negotiations between the White House and Congress that will follow the Senate's passage on Thursday of an immigration bill could decide not just how the nation confronts illegal immigration but also what strain of conservatism the Republican Party carries into the midterm elections and beyond.      Will it be the compassionate brand Mr. Bush considers crucial to the party's future, in this case by signaling support for a provision in the Senate bill that would give most illegal immigrants an opportunity to become legal? Or will it be the more doctrinaire variety embraced by much of Mr. Bush's party in the House, one that shuns anything that smacks of amnesty for illegal immigrants and seeks to criminalize them further?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 - The negotiations between the White House and Congress that will follow the Senate's passage on Thursday of an immigration bill could decide not just how the nation confronts illegal immigration but also what strain of conservatism the Republican Party carries into the midterm elections and beyond.

articles.headline: To Ease Standoff, Bush Seals Seized Files
articles.snippet: President Bush intervened directly Thursday in an increasingly tense constitutional fight between Congress and the Justice Department by ordering that records seized from a Congressional office over the weekend be sealed for 45 days.     ''Our gov...
articles.abstract: President Bush intervened directly Thursday in an increasingly tense constitutional fight between Congress and the Justice Department by ordering that records seized from a Congressional office over the weekend be sealed for 45 days.     ''Our government has not faced such a dilemma in more than two centuries,'' Mr. Bush said in his first statement on the swirl of events surrounding the Federal Bureau of Investigation's search of the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana, who has been accused of accepting bribes. ''Yet after days of discussions, it is clear these differences will require more time to be worked out.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 - President Bush intervened directly Thursday in an increasingly tense constitutional fight between Congress and the Justice Department by ordering that records seized from a Congressional office over the weekend be sealed for 45 days.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David Johnston

articles.headline: Election Battle: Will Peltz Win in Heinz Vote?
articles.snippet: THE big election campaign of 2006 got off to a rousing start this week, with the incumbents denounced for ''excessive costs and inefficiency'' that had hurt voters who deserved better.     In a plan with more than a passing resemblance to the tax ...
articles.abstract: THE big election campaign of 2006 got off to a rousing start this week, with the incumbents denounced for ''excessive costs and inefficiency'' that had hurt voters who deserved better.     In a plan with more than a passing resemblance to the tax cut promises that helped elect President Bush, the insurgents vowed to borrow money and put it in the pockets of voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE big election campaign of 2006 got off to a rousing start this week, with the incumbents denounced for "excessive costs and inefficiency" that had hurt voters who deserved better.

articles.headline: In Enron Case, a Verdict on an Era
articles.snippet: Guilty of crimes -- and a whole lot more.      Regardless of whether the jury verdict against Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling is upheld, testimony from 56 days of trial has sealed what is sure to be history's judgment -- one that is unlikel...
articles.abstract: Guilty of crimes -- and a whole lot more.      Regardless of whether the jury verdict against Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling is upheld, testimony from 56 days of trial has sealed what is sure to be history's judgment -- one that is unlikely to be vulnerable to appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Guilty of crimes -- and a whole lot more.

articles.headline: Atop Hedge Funds, Richest of the Rich Get Even More So
articles.snippet: Talk about minting money. In 2001 and 2002, hedge fund managers had to make $30 million to gain entry to a survey of the best paid in hedge funds that is closely followed by people in the business. In 2004, the threshold had soared to $100 million...
articles.abstract: Talk about minting money. In 2001 and 2002, hedge fund managers had to make $30 million to gain entry to a survey of the best paid in hedge funds that is closely followed by people in the business. In 2004, the threshold had soared to $100 million.     Last year, managers had to take home -- yes, take home -- $130 million to make it into the ranks of the top 25. And there was a tie for 25th place, so there were actually 26 hedge fund managers who made $130 million or more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about minting money. In 2001 and 2002, hedge fund managers had to make $30 million to gain entry to a survey of the best paid in hedge funds that is closely followed by people in the business. In 2004, the threshold had soared to $100 million.

articles.headline: Yahoo Makes Deal on Ads With eBay
articles.snippet: EBay and Yahoo, two top Internet companies that have been losing ground to Google, said yesterday that they would work together in several areas, including advertising and online payments.      The deal will expand Yahoo's share of Internet advert...
articles.abstract: EBay and Yahoo, two top Internet companies that have been losing ground to Google, said yesterday that they would work together in several areas, including advertising and online payments.      The deal will expand Yahoo's share of Internet advertising, a market where it lost leadership to Google. Investors have been worried that eBay's highly profitable shopping site is being undercut as consumers increasingly find products through search engines or through free listing services like Craigslist. Google and Yahoo have introduced similar free services.
articles.lead_paragraph: EBay and Yahoo, two top Internet companies that have been losing ground to Google, said yesterday that they would work together in several areas, including advertising and online payments.

articles.headline: Bush and Blair Concede Errors, but Defend War
articles.snippet: President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, two leaders badly weakened by the continuing violence in Iraq, acknowledged major misjudgments in the execution of the Iraq war on Thursday night even while insisting that the election of a ...
articles.abstract: President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, two leaders badly weakened by the continuing violence in Iraq, acknowledged major misjudgments in the execution of the Iraq war on Thursday night even while insisting that the election of a constitutional government in Baghdad justified their decision to go to war three years ago.     Speaking in subdued, almost chastened, tones at a joint news conference in the East Room, the two leaders steadfastly refused to talk about a schedule for pulling troops out of Iraq -- a pressure both men are feeling intently. They stuck to a common formulation that they would pull troops out only as properly trained Iraqi troops progressively took control over more and more territory in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 - President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, two leaders badly weakened by the continuing violence in Iraq, acknowledged major misjudgments in the execution of the Iraq war on Thursday night even while insisting that the election of a constitutional government in Baghdad justified their decision to go to war three years ago.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Military to Report Marines Killed Iraqi Civilians
articles.snippet: A military investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis last November is expected to find that a small number of marines in western Iraq carried out extensive, unprovoked killings of civilians, Congressional, military and Pentagon officials s...
articles.abstract: A military investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis last November is expected to find that a small number of marines in western Iraq carried out extensive, unprovoked killings of civilians, Congressional, military and Pentagon officials said Thursday.     Two lawyers involved in discussions about individual marines' defenses said they thought the investigation could result in charges of murder, a capital offense. That possibility and the emerging details of the killings have raised fears that the incident could be the gravest case involving misconduct by American ground forces in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 25 - A military investigation into the deaths of two dozen Iraqis last November is expected to find that a small number of marines in western Iraq carried out extensive, unprovoked killings of civilians, Congressional, military and Pentagon officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: This article is by Thom Shanker, Eric Schmitt and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: The Jurors Who Saw Through the Sideshow
articles.snippet: THE subtext of every criminal trial is, What is the jury thinking? The Enron trial was no different.      In the short time I was there, during the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling, I found myself searching for the tiniest clues -- just like every...
articles.abstract: THE subtext of every criminal trial is, What is the jury thinking? The Enron trial was no different.      In the short time I was there, during the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling, I found myself searching for the tiniest clues -- just like everyone else in the courtroom. The man with the mustache who took nonstop notes -- what did it mean when he put his notepad down and just stared at Mr. Skilling?
articles.lead_paragraph: THE subtext of every criminal trial is, What is the jury thinking? The Enron trial was no different.

articles.headline: Phone Tax Laid to Rest at Age 108
articles.snippet: Bowing to changes in technology and pressure from taxpayers and phone companies, the Treasury Department said yesterday that it would scrap the 108-year-old federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls. The move will bring consumers and busines...
articles.abstract: Bowing to changes in technology and pressure from taxpayers and phone companies, the Treasury Department said yesterday that it would scrap the 108-year-old federal excise tax on long-distance phone calls. The move will bring consumers and businesses about $15 billion in refunds on next year's tax returns.     The decision, which applies to cellphones and Internet phone services and some landlines, follows a series of court reversals for the government. Large businesses had successfully sued the Internal Revenue Service to recoup the taxes they paid. Phone companies also wanted the tax abolished to relieve them of having to collect it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Two Enron Chiefs Are Convicted in Fraud and Conspiracy Trial
articles.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the chief executives who guided Enron through its spectacular rise and even more stunning fall, were found guilty Thursday of fraud and conspiracy. They are among the most prominent corporate leaders convict...
articles.abstract: Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the chief executives who guided Enron through its spectacular rise and even more stunning fall, were found guilty Thursday of fraud and conspiracy. They are among the most prominent corporate leaders convicted in the parade of scandals that marked the get-rich-quick excesses and management failures of the 1990's.     The eight women and four men on the jury reached the verdicts after a little more than five days of deliberations. Mr. Skilling was convicted of 18 counts of fraud and conspiracy and one count of insider trading. He was acquitted on nine counts of insider trading. Mr. Lay was found guilty on six counts of fraud and conspiracy and four counts of bank fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 25 - Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the chief executives who guided Enron through its spectacular rise and even more stunning fall, were found guilty Thursday of fraud and conspiracy. They are among the most prominent corporate leaders convicted in the parade of scandals that marked the get-rich-quick excesses and management failures of the 1990's.

articles.headline: History's Judgment
articles.snippet: Enron will always stand for an era.   BY KURT EICHENWALD, PAGE C1
